item.title: Why Clean Code was (and still is) important?
item.description: In recent years, criticism of the classic object-oriented analysis and design ideas has grown increasingly louder. One example of such criticism is Clean Code, Horrible Performance by Case Muratori. Here’s a quote that explains the author’s idea: It simply cannot be the case that we’re willing to give up a decade or more of hardware performance just to make programmers’ lives a little bit easier. Our job is to write programs that run well on the hardware that we are given.
item.author: (Denis Bazhenov)

item.title: Paillier's additively homomorphic cryptosystem
item.description: Pascal Paillier released his asymmetric encryption algorithm in 1999, which had the particularity of being homomorphic for the addition. (And unlike RSA, the homomorphism was secure.) Homomorphic encryption, if you haven't heard of it, is the ability to operate on the ciphertext without having to decrypt it. If that still doesn't ring a bell, check my old blogpost on the subject. In this post I wi ...
